Situation1: The meeting is a routine catch-up that will be recorded for anyone who cannot make it.
Situation2: They find a broken lane rope that could disrupt swim lessons if not fixed soon.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the pool office wall, my laptop open and the team meeting about to start. As a colleague, I was expected to join in, share updates, and show I was part of the team—even if today’s meeting was just a routine catch-up and would be recorded for anyone who missed it. I logged in, ready to listen, when a swim instructor rushed in, breathless. “The lane rope’s snapped. Swim lessons start in ten minutes.” My heart sank. As the lifeguard, it was my job to keep the pool safe and the equipment in order. If I didn’t fix the rope now, the lessons would be chaotic, maybe even unsafe. But if I left the meeting, I’d look unreliable to my colleagues, like I didn’t care about the team. I stared at the screen, hearing my manager’s voice, while the broken rope waited outside. The pressure built inside me, torn between being a dependable teammate and a responsible lifeguard, knowing I couldn’t be both at once.
